overview.title: Defense in Depth
overview.description: iOS implements 9 complementary security mechanisms, from hardware to network. Each layer protects against specific threats. Click on a mechanism to learn more.
overview.attackFlowIntro: To compromise an iPhone, an attacker would need to:
overview.attackFlowConclusion: Bypassing all these protections simultaneously is extremely difficult, which explains why complete iOS exploits are worth millions of dollars.

attackSteps.step1: Secure Boot → Replace firmware/OS (impossible without Apple key)

secureboot.name: Secure Boot
secureboot.details: Verifies each boot component (Boot ROM → iBoot → Kernel) with cryptographic signatures. Prevents loading of modified firmware or OS.

secureenclave.name: Secure Enclave
secureenclave.details: Isolated coprocessor with its own OS and encrypted memory. Manages encryption keys, Face ID/Touch ID, and never shares secrets with the main processor.

dataprotection.name: Data Protection
dataprotection.details: Each file has its own AES-256 key. Protection classes determine when files are accessible (device locked, unlocked, etc.).
dataprotection.protects: Data theft if device is off/locked

codesigning.name: Code Signing
codesigning.details: All executable code must be signed by Apple or an approved developer. Guarantees authenticity and integrity of each application.

amfi.name: AMFI
amfi.details: Apple Mobile File Integrity verifies signatures at runtime via the kernel. Immediately blocks any modified or unsigned code.

sandbox.name: Sandbox
sandbox.details: Each app runs in its own isolated container with limited permissions. Must explicitly request access to system resources.

aslr.name: ASLR
aslr.details: Address Space Layout Randomization places code and data at random addresses with each execution. Makes memory exploits unpredictable.
aslr.protects: Buffer overflow, ROP attacks, memory exploits

xn.name: XN Bit
xn.details: Execute Never marks data zones as non-executable at CPU level. Even if code is injected, it cannot execute.

ats.name: ATS
ats.details: App Transport Security enforces HTTPS with TLS 1.2+ and valid certificates. Protects app network communications.

amfiTab.title: AMFI - Apple Mobile File Integrity
amfiTab.description: AMFI ensures that only signed and approved code can run on iOS. It verifies the integrity and authenticity of each executable before launch.
amfiTab.validSignatureDesc: The code is authentic and has not been modified since signing.
amfiTab.invalidSignatureDesc: The computed hash does not match the signature, or the signature is missing/invalid.
amfiTab.executionAllowedDesc: The application can run normally on the device.
amfiTab.executionDeniedDesc: AMFI prevents launch. User sees an error. Malicious or modified code cannot execute.
amfiTab.protection1: Launch verification: Each app is verified before execution
amfiTab.protection2: Page verification: Memory pages are verified during page faults
amfiTab.protection3: Dynamic libraries: Verification of loaded frameworks and dylibs
amfiTab.protection4: Continuous protection: Prevents code modification in memory
amfiTab.positionTitle: AMFI's position in defense in depth:
amfiTab.positionDesc: AMFI is the first line of defense. Before Sandbox, ASLR, or XN bit intervene, AMFI ensures that only legitimate and unmodified code can execute. It's the foundation on which all other protections rest.

step3.title: Invalid signature
step3.desc: Hash doesn't match or signature missing

secureBootTab.title: Secure Boot Chain - Chain of Trust
secureBootTab.description: Secure Boot ensures that only legitimate software signed by Apple can boot on the device. Each step cryptographically verifies the next before passing control, creating an unbroken chain of trust.
secureBootTab.fundamentalPrincipleDesc: The Boot ROM is the "root of trust" - it's immutable and can never be modified. All iOS security rests on this foundation.
secureBootTab.bootBlockedDesc: Secure Boot detected a modified component and immediately stopped the process. The device cannot boot and displays a recovery screen. Restore with iTunes/Finder to reinstall legitimate iOS.
secureBootTab.bootSuccessDesc: All steps verified successfully. iOS boots on a foundation of total trust - each component was cryptographically authenticated.
secureBootTab.protection1: Immutable Boot ROM: Cannot be modified, even with physical access
secureBootTab.protection2: RSA Signatures: Each component must be signed by Apple
secureBootTab.protection4: Anti-rollback protection: Prevents installation of vulnerable versions
secureBootTab.foundationTitle: Why it's the foundation of everything:
secureBootTab.foundationDesc: Without Secure Boot, all other protections (AMFI, Sandbox, Secure Enclave, etc.) could be bypassed by installing a malicious operating system. Secure Boot is the root of trust that ensures everything starts correctly.

codeSigningTab.title: Code Signing - Cryptographic Signature
codeSigningTab.description: Code Signing is the process by which Apple ensures each app comes from a known source and hasn't been modified since signing. It's the foundation that allows AMFI to verify code integrity.
codeSigningTab.entitlementsDesc: Entitlements define what the app is allowed to do. They are verified by the system at runtime.
codeSigningTab.amfiRelationDesc1: Code Signing is the process by which developers sign their apps with Apple certificates.
codeSigningTab.amfiRelationDesc2: AMFI is the verification mechanism that ensures at runtime the signature is valid and code hasn't been modified.
codeSigningTab.amfiRelationConclusion: Without Code Signing, AMFI would have nothing to verify. Together, they ensure only legitimate code runs on iOS.

step2.title: Compilation
step2.desc: Xcode compiles source code to Mach-O binary

step4.title: Cryptographic Signature
step4.desc: SHA-256 hash + Signature with developer certificate

step6.title: Apple Signature (if App Store)
step6.desc: Apple re-signs with its own certificate

atsTab.title: ATS - App Transport Security
atsTab.description: ATS forces all app network connections to use HTTPS with high security standards. It protects against man-in-the-middle attacks and ensures data in transit is encrypted.
atsTab.requirement3: Valid certificates signed by recognized CA
atsTab.analysisDesc: ATS intercepts the request and verifies protocol and security parameters
atsTab.secureConnectionDesc: All ATS criteria are met. Connection established securely with strong TLS encryption.
atsTab.warningConnectionDesc: An ATS exception was configured for this domain. Connection is allowed but not recommended for sensitive data.
atsTab.blockedConnectionDesc: ATS blocked this connection because it doesn't meet minimum security standards. App receives NSURLErrorAppTransportSecurityRequiresSecureConnection error.
atsTab.withoutATSDesc: An attacker on the same WiFi can intercept and read all data
atsTab.withATSDesc: Data is encrypted end-to-end, attacker only sees unreadable data

secureEnclaveTab.title: Secure Enclave - Security Coprocessor
secureEnclaveTab.description: The Secure Enclave is a secure coprocessor isolated from the main processor. It has its own operating system (sepOS) and handles all sensitive cryptographic operations.
secureEnclaveTab.step1Desc: TrueDepth camera captures and creates 3D face map
secureEnclaveTab.step2Desc: Data is sent to Secure Enclave for comparison. Biometric data NEVER leaves the Secure Enclave.
secureEnclaveTab.authSuccessDesc: Secure Enclave confirms match. Device is unlocked and encryption keys are released.
secureEnclaveTab.authFailedDesc: No match detected. Access denied. After 5 failures, a passcode is required.
secureEnclaveTab.protection1: Hardware isolation: Completely separate from main processor
secureEnclaveTab.protection2: Non-extractable keys: Crypto keys can never be read by iOS
secureEnclaveTab.protection3: Anti-replay protection: Attempt counter that cannot be reset
secureEnclaveTab.protection4: Secure boot: Secure Enclave has its own verified boot chain
secureEnclaveTab.whyCrucialDesc: Even if an attacker completely compromises iOS and gains root access, they cannot extract your cryptographic keys or biometric data from the Secure Enclave. It's an independent hardware fortress.

dataProtectionTab.title: Data Protection - Data Encryption
dataProtectionTab.description: iOS encrypts each file with its own unique key. Keys are protected by user passcode and managed by Secure Enclave. Different protection classes determine when files are accessible.
dataProtectionTab.hardwareKey: Hardware key (unique per device, etched in silicon)
dataProtectionTab.hardwareKeyUIDDesc: Unique per device, etched in silicon during manufacturing. Impossible to extract.
dataProtectionTab.userCodeDesc: Derived from user passcode/Face ID via Secure Enclave.
dataProtectionTab.derivedClassKeyDesc: Used to decrypt individual file keys (AES-256).
dataProtectionTab.attackProtection1: Device theft: Without passcode, impossible to decrypt
dataProtectionTab.attackProtection2: Data extraction: Files remain encrypted outside device
dataProtectionTab.attackProtection3: Brute force attack: Secure Enclave enforces increasing delays

sandboxTab.title: Sandbox - Application Isolation
sandboxTab.description: Each iOS app runs in its own isolated "sandbox". It can only access its own data and must request permission to access system resources.
sandboxTab.accessDeniedPhotos: The malicious app doesn't have permission to access your photos.
sandboxTab.accessDeniedContacts: The malicious app doesn't have permission to access your contacts.
sandboxTab.accessDeniedSystem: The malicious app doesn't have permission to access these system files.
sandboxTab.accessDeniedDesc: The sandbox blocks any unauthorized access attempt.
sandboxTab.restriction1: Each app has its own isolated directory

aslrTab.title: ASLR - Address Space Layout Randomization
aslrTab.description: ASLR randomizes memory addresses with each program execution. Click "New execution" to simulate a restart and observe how addresses change each time.
aslrTab.protectionActiveDesc: All addresses have changed. An attacker cannot predict where functions or data are located in memory, making exploitation much harder.
aslrTab.whyImportant1: Without ASLR, addresses would always be identical
aslrTab.whyImportant2: Attackers could predict where to attack in memory
aslrTab.whyImportant3: With ASLR, each execution has unique memory layout
aslrTab.whyImportant4: Exploits based on fixed addresses become impossible

xnBitTab.title: How the XN Bit Works
xnBitTab.description: The XN (eXecute Never) bit marks certain memory zones as NON-EXECUTABLE. Even if an attacker injects malicious code, the processor refuses to execute it.
xnBitTab.detectionDesc: CPU detects execution attempt at address 0x7FF010 which is marked with XN bit (non-executable)
xnBitTab.protectionActivatedDesc: System terminates process immediately. Attacker cannot execute malicious code. Application crashes rather than being compromised.

step1.title: Normal situation
step1.desc: Program runs normally with code and data separated

step2.title: Injection attempt
step2.desc: Attacker attempts to inject malicious code into stack (data zone)

step3.title: XN Bit intervenes
step3.desc: Processor detects execution attempt in zone marked non-executable

step4.title: Attack blocked
step4.desc: System immediately terminates process (crash) - attack fails
